facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 621 of 1961 before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 621 of 1961.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated September 25, 1958 of Kerala High Court in Tax Revision Case No. 11 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 25, 1958, of the Kerala High Court in Tax Revision Case No. 11 of 1957.

facts.text: Appellant is the State of Kerala.

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal by special leave against the judgment and order of the High Court of Kerala the appellant is the State of Kerala

facts.text: Respondent is the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant is the State of Kerala and the respondent is the assessec.

facts.text: Proceedings under Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939 read with rules under s.19.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal arises out of proceedings under the Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939,  Madras Act No. IX of 1939  read with the rules made under s. 19 of that Act.

facts.text: Kozhikode area transferred from State of Madras to State of Kerala by States Reorganisation Act.

anchor.surface_text: The area of Kozhikode was originally within the State of Madras, but by the States Reorganisation Act was transferred to the State of Kerala.

facts.text: Madras General Sales Tax Act continued to apply in Kerala.

anchor.surface_text: The Madras General Sales Tax Act, however, companytinued to apply.

facts.text: Assessment period for turnover in dispute is 1952-53.

anchor.surface_text: The assessment period for the purposes of the turnover in dispute is 1952-53.

facts.text: Deputy Commercial Tax Officer, Kozhikode imposed sales tax on respondent on net turnover of Rs. 12,56,178-14-0 by order dated March 27, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: By an order dated March 27, 1954 the Deputy Commercial Tax Officer, Kozhikode, imposed sales tax on the respondent on a net turnover of Rs. 12,56,178-14-0

facts.text: Appeal against order dated March 27, 1954 to Commercial Tax Officer was dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: and the appeal taken against that order to the Commercial Tax Officer was dismissed.

facts.text: Notice issued by Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes on March 15, 1956 proposing to determine escaped turnover.

anchor.surface_text: On March 15, 1956 a numberice was issued by the Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes against the assessee proposing to determine the escaped turnover

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner determined revised turnover by order dated March 31, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: By an order dated March 31, 1956, the Deputy Commissioner determined the revised turnover.

facts.text: Appeal against Deputy Commissioner's order to Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal, Trivandrum dismissed on March 23, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: An appeal was taken against that order to the Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal, Trivandrum, but that appeal was dismissed on March 23, 1957.

facts.text: Revision to Kerala High Court against Tribunal order; High Court set aside Deputy Commissioner's order dated March 31, 1956 on ground that notice was without jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: Against that order a revision was taken to the Kerala High Court and by its judgment dated September 25, 1958 the High Court set aside the order of the Deputy Commissioner on the ground that the numberice issued by the Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes was without jurisdiction

facts.text: High Court did not decide whether rule under which Deputy Commissioner acted was ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: and the order of the appellate tribunal was therefore erroneous. Another question which had been raised before the High Court that the rule under which the Deputy Commissioner purported to act was ultra vires the Act was number decided

facts.text: State of Kerala appealed to Supreme Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Against that judgment and order the State of Kerala has companye in appeal by special leave to this companyrt.

facts.text: Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal held that powers under s.12(2) and r.17(3A) are distinct and action under r.17(3A) was not without jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal held that the powers companyferred on the Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes under s. 12 2  and r. 17 3A  are distinct powers and action taken under r. 17 3A  was number without jurisdiction.

facts.text: Kerala High Court reversed Tribunal's finding on jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: This finding was reversed by the High Court.

facts.text: Appellant State contended that notice issued by Deputy Commissioner was not without jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: One on behalf of the appellant the State of Kerala that the numberice issued by the Deputy Commissioner was number without jurisdiction and the High Courts opinion on that point is erroneous

facts.text: Respondent assessee contended that the rule under which notice issued was ultra vires the Act.

anchor.surface_text: and the second on behalf of the respondent assessee that if the numberice was number without jurisdiction then the rule under which the numberice was issued was altra vires as it was beyond the substantive provisions of the Act.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on October 11, 1962 by KAPUR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. October 11. The judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, J.-

anchor.surface_text: Section 11 deals with appeals and s. 12 with the power of the Sales tax authorities to pass orders in revision. That sub-section is as follows- S. 12  1  The Commercial Tax Officer may i   i   ii  The Deputy Commissioner may- suo motu or in respect of an order passed or proceeding recorded by the Commercial Tax Officer under sub-section  1  or any other provision of this Act and against which numberappeal has been preferred to the Appellants Tribunal under s. 12 A on application, call for and examine the record of any order passed or proceeding recorded under the provisions of this Act by any Officer subordinate to him, for the purpose of satisfying himself as to the legality or propriety of such order, or as to the regularity of such proceeding and may pass such order with respect thereto as he thinks fit.

anchor.surface_text: Section 19 gives power to the Government to make rules and the relevant provisions of that section are 119  1  and 19  2   f . They are as under- 19  1  The State Government may make rules to carry out the purposes of this Act. In particular and without prejudice to the generality of foregoing power such rules may provide for-  f  the assessment to tax under this Act of any turnover which has escaped assessment and the period within which such assessment may be made, number exceeding three years

concepts.unlisted_description: Rules for assessment of escaped turnover

anchor.surface_text: Under the rule making power companyferred by s. 19 rules have been framed and we are companycerned in this appeal with rr. 17  1 , 17  IA  and 1.7  3A . They read as under- 17  1  If for any reason the whole or any part of the turnover of business of a dealer or licensee has escaped assessment to the tax in any year or if the licence fee has escaped levy in any year, the assessing authority or licensing authority, as the case may be,  subject to the provisions  in sub-rule  1-A  may, at any time within three years next succeeding that which the tax or licence fee relates  determine to the best of his judgment the turnover which has escaped assessment and assess the tax payable in such turnover  or levy the licence fee after issuing a numberice to the dealer or licensee and after making such enquiry as he companysiders necessary. 17  1A  Where in respect of the turnover referred to in sub-rule 1 an order has already been passed under section 11 or 12 the assessing authority shall make a report to the appropriate appellate or revising authority as the case may be, which shall thereupon after giving the dealer companycerned reasonable opportunity of being heard, pass such orders as it deems fit. 17  3A  The powers companyferred by sub-rules 1 and 3 on assessing authority or licensing authority may also be exercised by the appel- Iate authority referred to in section II or as the case may be, by the revising authority referred to in section 12, at any time within a period of three years next succeeding that which the tax, or as the case may be, the licence fee relates provided that such authority shall give the, dealer companycerned a reasonable opportunity of being heard before, passing orders under this sub- rule.

issues.text: Whether the notice issued by the Deputy Commissioner was without jurisdiction?

anchor.surface_text: One on behalf of the appellant the State of Kerala that the notice issued by the Deputy Commissioner was not without jurisdiction and the High Courts opinion on that point is erroneous

issues.text: Whether the rule under which the notice was issued (r.17) was ultra vires as it was beyond the substantive provisions of the Act?

anchor.surface_text: and the second on behalf of the respondent assessee that if the notice was not without jurisdiction then the rule under which the notice was issued was ultra vires as it was beyond the substantive provisions of the Act.

issues.text: Whether the powers conferred on the Deputy Commissioner under s.12(2) and r.17(3A) are distinct?

anchor.surface_text: We shall first take up the question of jurisdiction raised by the appellant. The tribunal held that the powers conferred on the Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes under s. 12 (2) and r. 17 (3A) are distinct powers and action taken under r. 17 (3A) was not without jurisdiction.

issues.text: Whether sub-rule 3A of r.17 is confined to cases where revision under s.12(2) is pending?

anchor.surface_text: The further argument that sub-r. 3A is confined to cases where the revision filed under s. 12 (2) is pending is not supported by the language of that rule.

arguments.claim: The powers conferred on the Deputy Commissioner under s.12(2) and r.17(3A) are distinct powers and action taken under r.17(3A) was not without jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal held that the powers conferred on the Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes under s. 12 2  and r. 17 3A  are distinct powers and action taken under r. 17 3A  was not without jurisdiction.

arguments.claim: Powers under s.12(2) and r.17(3A) are distinct; escaped assessment power under r.17 not arising from revisional jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: But the power to assess escaped turnover does not arise out of the revisional jurisdiction. In exercising revisional jurisdiction the Deputy Commissioner would be restricted to the examination of the record for determining whether the order of assessment was according to law.

arguments.claim: r.17 validly made under s.19; falls under s.19(2)(f) or general s.19(1) power which is not restricted by sub-s.(2)

anchor.surface_text: Rule 17(1) and (3A) ex facie properly fall under s. 19(2)(f). In any event as was said by the Privy Council in King Emperor v. Sibnath Banerji the rule making power is conferred by sub-s.(1) of that section and the function of sub-s.(2) is merely illustrative

arguments.claim: r.17 within rule-making power under s.19(1) to carry out Act's purposes (levy of sales tax)

anchor.surface_text: sub-s. 1 of s. 19 of the Act provides that the State Government may make rules to carry out the purposes of this Act and the long title of the Act is an Act to provide for the levy of general tax on the sale of goods

arguments.claim: s.2B authorizes State to appoint Deputy Commissioners who can exercise powers under r.17

anchor.surface_text: The answer to this is in s. 2B. That section authorises the State Government to appoint as many Deputy Commissioners of Commercial Taxes as it thinks fit for the purpose of performing the functions conferred on them under the Act

arguments.claim: s.9 deals only with initial assessment, not escaped turnover; no conflict with s.12(2) or r.17

anchor.surface_text: Provisions of s. 9(1) and (2) therefore are not bar to the exercise of power of assessing escaped turnovers. Moreover s. 9 does not deal with escaped turnovers but is a provision for the determination of the turnover of a dealer in the first instance

arguments.claim: r.17(3A) confined to cases where revision under s.12(2) is pending

anchor.surface_text: The further argument that sub-r. 3A is confined to cases where the revision filed under s. 12(2) is pending is not supported by the language of that rule.

arguments.court_reasoning: Language of rule does not support such limitation

arguments.claim: Sub-r.3A confers jurisdiction on revising authority to assess escaped turnover even without pending revision under s.12(2)

anchor.surface_text: There is then a third case and that is where there has been no appeal or revision under ss. 11 and 12 of the Act and therefore no order of the appellate authority or of revisional authority as contemplated in s. 12(2) of the Act and in those cases the appellate authority or the revising authority as the case may be has, under sub-r. 3A, the same power as the assessing authority had under sub-r. 1 of r.

holdings.text: Sub-rule 3A of r. 17 on its plain construction confers jurisdiction on the revising authority to issue the notice which it did issue and the judgment of the High Court is erroneous and it cannot be said that the notice was without jurisdiction
holdings.reasoning_summary: r.17(3A) independently empowers revising authority to assess escaped turnover after notice and hearing, distinct from s.12(2) revisional power limited to record examination; applies to facts where no further appeal/revision after Commercial Tax Officer

holdings.text: r. 17 and the various clauses thereof made under s. 19 are not beyond the rule making power of the State Government as contained in s. 19

anchor.surface_text: Therefore in our opinion r. 17 and the various clauses thereof made under s. 19 are number beyond the rule making power of the State Government as contained in s. 19. The first sub-rule of r. 17 provides that the assessing authority may subject to sub-r. IA at any time within three years next succeeding that to which the tax relates determine the turnover which has escaped assessment and assess the tax payable on such turnover.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.19(1) confers general rule-making power for Act's purposes (levy of sales tax); s.19(2)(f) illustrative per Privy Council in King Emperor v. Sibnath Banerji; r.17 falls within or ex facie under it

holdings.text: The power to assess escaped turnover does not arise out of the revisional jurisdiction under s.12(2); powers under s.12(2) and r.17(3A) are distinct

anchor.surface_text: But the power to assess escaped turnover does number arise out of the revisional jurisdiction. In exercising revisional jurisdiction the Deputy Commissioner would be restricted to the examination of the record for determining whether the order of assessment was according to law. Rule 17 confers power to assess escaped turnover which may numbermally be exercised on matters dehors the record of assessment proceedings before the Deputy Commercial Tax Officer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.12(2) limited to legality/propriety/regularity of subordinate's record; r.17 confers separate direct power to assess escaped turnover even dehors record

holdings.text: Provisions of s.9(1) and (2) are not a bar to the exercise of power of assessing escaped turnovers; s.9 deals only with initial assessment

anchor.surface_text: Provisions of s. 9 1  and  2  therefore are numberbar to the exercise of power of assessing escaped turnovers. Moreover s. 9 does number deal with escaped turnovers but is a provision for the determination of the turnover of a dealer in the first instance number can it be said that r. 17 is in companyflict with s. 12 2 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.9 for first instance dealer turnover determination; escaped turnover addressed by rules under s.19; assessing authority defn in s.2(a-2) satisfied by s.2B appointment of Deputy Commissioners

holdings.text: The provisions of s.12(2) are in no way in conflict with the powers conferred under r.17(1), 17(1A) and 17(3A); Rule 17 deals with a separate and independent jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: It cannot be said in view of r. 17 that the power of revision by the Deputy Commissioners is limited to powers under s. 12 2 . Rule 17 deals with a separate and independent jurisdiction in regard to the determining and taxing escaped turnovers. The provisions of s. 12 2  are in numberway in companyflict with the powers companyferred under r. 17 1 , 17 IA  and 17 3A .

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.12(2) concerns another jurisdiction (suo motu review of subordinate orders); r.17 independent for escaped turnover even without invoking revision

holdings.text: sub-r. 3A is not confined to cases where the revision filed under s.12(2) is pending

anchor.surface_text: The further argument that sub-r. 3A is companyfined to cases where the revision filed under s. 12 2  is pending is number supported by the language of that-rule.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain language of r.17(3A) confers power on revising authority at any time within 3 years, independent of any pending s.12(2) revision; covers cases with no appeal/revision after initial assessment

precedents.citation: King Emperor v. Sibnath Banerji 1 1945 L. R. 72 I. A. 241

anchor.surface_text: In any event as was said by the Privy Council in King Emperor v. Sibnath Banerji 1  the rule making power is companyferred by sub-s.  1  of that section and the function of subs.  2  is merely illustrative and the rules which are referred to in sub-s. 2 are authorised by and made under sub-s. 1. The provisions of sub-s. 2 arc number restrictive of sub-s.  1  as expressly stated in the words without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing power with which sub-s.  2  begins and which words arc similar to the words of sub-s.  2  of s. 2 of the Defence of India Act which the Privy Council was companysidering.

precedents.cited_proposition: the rule making power is conferred by sub-s. 1 of that section and the function of subs. 2 is merely illustrative and the rules which are referred to in sub-s. 2 are authorised by and made under sub-s. 1. The provisions of sub-s. 2 are not restrictive of sub-s. 1 as expressly stated in the words without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing power with which sub-s. 2 begins
